warmup.title: Why Warm Up?
warmup.content: A proper warm-up increases blood flow to muscles, raises body temperature, and prepares your nervous system for the workout ahead. This can improve performance by 10-20% and significantly reduce injury risk.

warmup.title: Chest Day Prep
warmup.content: Before pressing movements, focus on warming up your rotator cuff and scapular muscles. Healthy shoulders are essential for a strong chest workout.

warmup.title: Protect Your Spine
warmup.content: For back exercises, especially deadlifts and rows, thoracic mobility is crucial. Cat-cow stretches and thoracic rotations prepare your spine for heavy loads.

warmup.title: Never Skip Leg Warmups
warmup.content: Your legs contain the largest muscles in your body. A thorough lower body warm-up, including hip circles and bodyweight squats, prevents strains and improves squat depth.

warmup.title: Shoulder Mobility Matters
warmup.content: The shoulder is the most mobile joint in your body but also the most vulnerable. Band dislocations and external rotations keep your rotator cuff healthy.

cooldown.title: Why Cool Down?
cooldown.content: Cooling down gradually lowers your heart rate, prevents blood pooling in your extremities, and starts the recovery process. Stretching while muscles are warm improves flexibility.

cooldown.title: Static Stretching Benefits
cooldown.content: Post-workout is the ideal time for static stretching. Hold each stretch for 30-60 seconds to promote muscle relaxation and reduce next-day soreness.

cooldown.title: Foam Rolling Recovery
cooldown.content: Foam rolling after your workout helps break up muscle adhesions, improves blood flow, and can reduce delayed onset muscle soreness (DOMS) by up to 20%.

recovery.title: Sleep Is Gains
recovery.content: Most muscle repair and growth hormone release occurs during deep sleep. Aim for 7-9 hours per night, especially after intense training sessions.

recovery.title: Hydration Matters
recovery.content: Even mild dehydration can reduce strength by 10-20%. Drink water throughout the day, not just during your workout.
